awd_titl_txt: Structure Regulation of Ionic Copolymers: Unlocking Ionic Clusters through Solvent Shear Adaptation, a Computational-Experimental Insight
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

This project focuses on ionic copolymers, a family of macromolecules comprised of segments that enable ionic transport, tethered to ones that can enhance mechanical stability. Such polymer materials show promise as membranes for use in innovative technologies, for example, light-weight clean energy generation and storage, water purification, and biomedical applications. However, scientists cannot yet control the structures these polymers form during their processing into membranes. This presents a significant roadblock since these structures determine the properties of the polymer films, and hence control their potential use for devices.  The membrane structure is governed by interactions among the polymer blocks and between each of the blocks with the solvent, as well as processing conditions. The barrier to controlling the structure stems from the tendency of the ionic segments to aggregate and form regions that remain trapped and "lock" the polymers during membrane formation.  Using computational tools supported by experimental studies, the project will determine the structure evolution of ionic co-polymers in elongational flow and as the solvents evaporate. The working hypothesis is that "unlocking" the ionic clusters without "locking" the rest of the blocks, through solvent tuning under flow, will enable the formation of controlled, well-defined structured membranes of ionic co-polymers. With advanced computational tools, coupled with structure determination techniques, the project will provide fundamental insights into polymer processing. This knowledge will directly promote the progress of science and technologies that will advance the economic health and prosperity of the nation.  


TECHNICAL SUMMARY: 

With the grand challenge of understanding ionic polymers under dynamic conditions, the research will strive to capture the time evolution of the structure of ionic block co-polymers in solutions in elongational flow and as solvents evaporate. The study will capture polymer processing fundamentals, using non-equilibrium molecular dynamics simulations, supported by selective neutron studies. The working hypothesis of the proposed research is that "unlocking" the ionic clusters without "locking" the hydrophobic blocks will enable the formation of controlled well-defined structures in ionic copolymer membranes. This process is achievable by manipulating a solvent-flow manifold that will control the structure of ionic copolymers and consequently their properties.  A set of well-defined diblocks and triblocks that contain polystyrene sulfonate ionizable blocks, in solutions of selective solvents for each of the blocks and theta-solvents for all blocks, will be studied in elongational flow and as the solvents evaporate. The study will resolve the parameters that lead to the "unlocked-unlocked" state for all blocks under dynamic conditions, and its effect on the overall structure of the neat ionizable phases. Understanding the delicate balance of several highly incompatible blocks and their interactions with solvents under quiescent conditions and under flow fields presents experimental and computational challenges. However, the convergence of computational studies and experimental efforts following the structure evolution of ionic co-polymers solvent-flow response will provide the required multi-time-length-scale insight essential to drive the structure of ionizable copolymers.
.

Research Outcomes

Macromolecules, capable of charge transport enable current and potential new technologies such as light-weight clean energy generation and storage, water purification, and biotechnology.  Tethering multiple blocks into one macromolecule enables tailoring desired functions into a lightweight matrix, where the ionizable blocks facilitate transport and the other segments control the mechanical stability.  This seemingly simple idea of macromolecules that consist of multiple blocks, each with distinctive characteristics and response, remains a challenge, particularly under operation conditions where solvents, mechanical stress and often electrical fields are present, affecting each of the constituents differently.  

With the ultimate goal of controlling the structure and motion of structured ionizable co-polymers and their response to stimuli, we were able to correlate the mechanical response of model ionizable co-polymers with the properties of the chemistries and topology of such polymers using elastic and quasi elastic neutron scattering techniques coupled with molecular dynamics simulations (MD).  The research took major strides towards understanding the response of a family of structured co-polymers with polystyrene sulfonate as the ionizable block tethered to polyethylene propylene end-capped with t-butyl styrene, through following the individual blocks and the entire polymer.  Overall, we were able to directly couple dynamics on the bond length scale to the mesoscopic scale, where the motion of the entire macromolecule is expressed.

Enabled by direct coupling of large-scale MD simulations with experimental scattering results, we were able to provide insight into  a long-standing challenge in polymers, which has an immense impact on processing macromolecules into viable materials.   

I- Mechanical Response  The first step on route to understanding the mechanical response of ionizable co-polymers, we focused on the individual blocks, starting with impact of dispersity of polyethylene, followed by the effect of polymer topology.    We were able to correlate the dispersity of linear polymers and branching characteristics of comb-like polymers with stress relaxation and shear viscosity of entangled polyethylene melts.  We find that a slight polydispersity is sufficient to alter the mechanical response of a melt, where the  shorter chains act as a solvent. Similarly, we  were  able to corelate  the topology with the size and density of branches in comb polymers.

II Charge Distribution-Topology Effects on Structure  Increasing complexity of the polymers, through adding associative groups (that model the ionizable moieties), the structure, and dynamics  in linear and star polymers and their blends, were  identified, as the associating group strength was varied.  For all systems, the associating groups drive cluster formation.  We find that the strength of the interaction of the associating groups, defines  their structure.

III-Ionizable co-polymers

a) The structure and dynamics of a polystyrene sulfonate homologous series were studied as the distribution of the ionizable group varied from random to distinctive blocks, using fully atomistic MD simulations. We find that the distribution of the ionic groups affects the shape and the cluster size as well as the internal packing of the ionizable groups within the cluster.   We derived for the first time the correlation between the number of polymer chains associated with specific clusters and the dynamics of the polymers.

b) The structure and dynamics of the symmetric  pentablock ionizable copolymer,  were studied in solvents of varying dielectric constants using large scale MD simulations. Independent of the solvents, this pentablock co-polymer forms a core–shell micelle with the ionizable segment segregating to the core.  The structure of each of the blocks strongly depends on the sulfonation levels and the dielectric constant and the polarity of the solvents.

 IV Methodology Development  We were able to adapt  our computational algorithms to study large systems of structured ionizable co-polymers under flow and extract meaningful results. An example of polymers under flow  is given in image I.

 

The Broader Impact Outcomes

The broader impact includes educational initiatives, broadening participation, advancing research methodologies and driving technology, for betterment of society.   

Neutron/Computational training has been the hallmark of the educational efforts of our program.  Two of the students that worked on the project have assumed positions in National Laboratories, and one took a postdoctoral position at ORNL. A computational student just finished an internship in neutron scattering at ORNL. Image II highlights neutron scattering activities of the PI.

The PI has been actively promoting interdisciplinary research through organizing multiple sessions at the APS March meetings, through DPOLY and GSNP that promote experimental -computational efforts.   Among the  highlights are a 2022 symposium “From Statistical Physics to High Performance Materials” to celebrate the work of Mark Robbins and 2023 APS March Meeting symposia, bridging between statistical physics and topology of polymers; organized together with S. S. Grest.

Public Outreach As part of  the PI involvement is reaching out to the community, at the 2024 March APS meeting  she was part of the team that ran the “Squishy  Physics” event  that was organized by the American Physical Society.
